text: {{Infobox writer | name = John Irving | image = John Irving at Cologne 2010 (7108).jpg | caption = Irving in Cologne, Germany, September 14, 2010 | birth_name = John Wallace Blunt Jr. | birth_date = | birth_place = Exeter, New Hampshire, U.S. | occupation = | alma_mater = | notableworks = | awards = | website = }} John Winslow Irving (born John Wallace Blunt Jr.; March 2, 1942) is an American-Canadian novelist, short story writer, and screenwriter. Irving was born in Exeter, New Hampshire. His parents divorced before he was born. His name was changed when his mother married again. His step-father was a teacher at Phillips Exeter Academy. When he graduated from there, Irving went to the University of Pittsburgh. After one year there, he went to study in Vienna, Austria. He came back to the United States to study at the University of Iowa Writers' Workshop. One of his teachers there was Kurt Vonnegut, Jr.. In Iowa, he wrote his first novel, Setting Free the Bears. He became well-known in 1978 when The World According to Garp came out. It was a finalist for the National Book Award for Fiction in 1979. In 1999 he won an Academy Award for his screenplay of his novel The Cider House Rules. In 2018, he won the Richard C. Holbrooke Distinguished Achievement Award. ==Books== *Setting Free the Bears (1968) *The Water-Method Man (1972) *The 158-Pound Marriage (1974) *The World According to Garp (1978) *The Hotel New Hampshire (1981) *The Cider House Rules (1985) *A Prayer for Owen Meany (1989) *A Son of the Circus (1994) *Trying to Save Piggy Sneed (1996) *A Widow for One Year (1998) *The Fourth Hand (2001) *Until I Find You (2005) *Last Night in Twisted River (2009) *In One Person (2012) *Avenue of Mysteries (2015) *The Last Chairlift (2022) ==References== Category:1942 births Category:American short story writers Category:American novelists Category:Living people Category:American screenwriters Category:Writers from New Hampshire
